questions.text: The most common cause of anesthetic complications
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Human error The most common cause of anesthetic complications is human errors but not necessarily negligence.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Equipment malfunction is often considered as a common cause of complications however it’s not as common as human error. In fact, inability to detect equipment malfunction will also be considered a human error. Option C : Drug anaphylaxis is very rare Option D : Drug side effects can cause complications but again not able to detect these side effects will be also be considered a human error.

questions.text: Incidence of anesthesia-related mortality:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 in 200000 Death in the perioperative period is multifactorial. It may be due to a patient's pre-existing morbidities (The risk ratio of dying in theperioperative period between ASA 3-5 vs ASA 1-2 is 10.65), surgical complications, etc. The incidence of death related purely to Anesthesia is 1:185,056

questions.text: Maximum cardiac arrest occurs during:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Induction More than 80% of cardiac arrest occurs at the time of induction.

Highyeild:

The three most common causes of anesthesia-related cardiac arrest (in decreasing order) are: Inadequate ventilation Asystole after succinylcholine postinduction hemodynamic instability.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D : Cardiac arrest can occur at any time in the perioperative period due to multiple reasons like drug anaphylaxis, hypoxia, hemodynamic instability, arrhythmias, etc. however maximum cardiac arrests have been reported at the time of induction.

questions.text: The most common type of hypoxia seen during anesthesia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypoxic Hypoxic hypoxia is the most common type of hypoxia seen during anesthesia which can occur due to multiple causes like failure to ventilate, decreased oxygen supply, aspiration, hypoventilation, etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Anemia hypoxia can occur in the perioperative period if the patient bleeds too much and has not been adequately replaced with transfusion. Another cause of anemic hypoxia may be carbon monoxide poising which can happen if desiccated soda lime is used with Desflurane. Option C: Stagnant hypoxia can occur if there is significant hypotension due to blood loss or arrhythmia. Option D: Histotoxic hypoxia is very rare in the perioperative period nowadays. It was seen in the past when sodium nitroprusside was used to produce controlled hypotension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old under laparotomy under GA. The patient's oxygen saturation was found to be subnormal in the post-operative period. The most common postoperative pulmonary complication:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atelectasis The most common cause of postoperative hypoxia is atelectasis of a segment or lobe which in turn occurs because of bronchial obstruction by secretions.

Highyeild:

After shunt (V/Q mismatch) second most common cause of hypoxemia in the postoperative period is hypoventilation which may be because of the: Overdose of opioids, inhalational agents, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates. Inadequate reversal. Pain. High spinal/epidural. CNS disorders. Cardiac event (like myocardial ischemia).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Pulmonary embolism may occur in prolonged surgeries particularly if the patient has risk factors also like immobilization, pre-existing hypercoagulable condition, etc. however pulmonary embolism is a rare complication Option C: Aspiration is also a known complication but significant aspiration is a rare complication. Option D: Theoretically intubation can dislodge bacteria from the oral cavity into the lungs leading to bacterial pneumonia, however practically it is rare in short-duration intibutions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old trauma patient is undergoing an emergency craniotomy for extradural hematoma drainage. As per the relative’s patient took a meal 2 hours before. All of the following statements about aspiration are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: In the supine position, the most commonly involved part of the lung is the apical segment of the left lower lobe

options.label: B
options.text: The critical intragastric pressure at which aspiration occurs is 20 cmH2O

options.label: C
options.text: It is a preventable complication of GA

options.label: D
options.text: Significant aspiration occurs if the aspirated volume is more than 25 ml

questions.correct_answer: A. In the supine position, the most commonly involved part of the lung is the apical segment of the left lower lobe
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In the supine position, the most commonly involved part of the lung is the apical segment of the left lower lobe In the supine position, the most commonly involved part of the lung is the apical segment of the right lower lobe, not the left lower lobe.

Highyeild:

In the lateral position posterior segment of the upper lobe is most commonly affected while basal segments are involved if the patient aspirates in a standing/sitting position.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Normal intragastric pressure is 5-7 cmH2O. The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) becomes incompetent if pressure is above 20 cmH2O. In conditions like pregnancy, hiatus hernia a pressure of only 15 cmH2O can overcome the competency of LES. Option C: Although it is not possible to always prevent aspiration however still it is considered a preventable complication. The most important preventing measure to prevent aspiration is to keep the patient fasting as per guidelines for fasting Option D: The most important factor determining the severity of aspiration pneumonitis is the volume of aspirated material. Volume > 25 ml is considered a significant volume to cause aspiration. The other two important factors are Ph < 2.5 and solid consistency.

questions.text: All of the following are predisposing factors for aspiration except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metoclopramide Metoclopramide can protect against aspiration by increasing the tone of LES and increasing gastric emptying.

Highyeild:

A full stomach is the single most important factor for aspiration. Other factors are: Decreased level of consciousness. Conditions decreasing the tone of LES like: Pregnancy Hiatus hernia Atropine Opioids Abdominal tumors Obesity Conditions delaying gastric emptying like: diabetes narcotics hypothyroidism.

questions.text: During rapid sequence induction of anesthesia:

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is mechanically ventilated before endotracheal intubation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reoxygenation is mandatory As bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated during rapid sequence induction, preoxygenation becomes mandatory.

Highyeild:

The rapid sequence (crash) intubation technique is applied to full-stomach patients. In this technique: Premedication is done with metoclopramide and ranitidine. Preoxygenation is done for 3-5 minutes. An intravenous induction agent is given. Ketamine is the preferred agent for induction because it maximally preserves airway reflexes. Succinylcholine is given. As soon as succinylcholine is given the assistant applies cricoid pressure. This is called Sellick's Cricoid pressure will compress the esophagus between the fingers and vertebral column preventing aspiration. Positive pressure ventilation with a bag and mask is CI because air can leak into the stomach and can raise the intragastric pressure above the critical pressure. Cricoid pressure is relieved only after the cuff is inflated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Sellicks maneuvered must be applied Option C: As bag and mask ventilation is not done, it's very important to intubate the patient as fast as possible. As Suxamethonium has a fast onset of 20-30 seconds, it is the muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence induction Option D: positive pressure ventilation before intubation is absolutely C/I during rapid sequence induction

questions.text: Bag and mask ventilation is CI in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital lobar emphysema Bag and mask ventilation is not C/I in congenital lobar pneumonia

Highyeild:

CI for bag and mask ventilation are: Full stomach patient Patients at high risk of aspiration like pregnancy, and hiatus hernia. Intestinal obstruction. Diaphragmatic hernia. Tracheoesophageal fistula. Meconium aspiration.

questions.text: Modified Sellick’s maneuver is

options.label: A
options.text: Using negative pressure during the Sellicks maneuver

questions.correct_answer: B. Cricoid pressure with mask ventilation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cricoid pressure with mask ventilation In the modified Sellicks maneuver cricoid pressure is maintained while the patient is undergoing mask ventilation with gentle IPPV (< 20 cmH20). This is generally employed in situations where there is less oxygen reserve or difficult intubation is anticipated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: There is no method where negative pressure is given during anesthesia. Option C: The patient aspirates once he/she becomes unconscious and loses his/her airway reflexes. Therefore, cricoid pressure should be applied once the patient falls asleep not just before intubation Option D: Although cricoid pressure does not 100% guarantee against aspiration however giving cricoid pressure can decrease the chances of aspiration. Therefore, it should be applied for all cases where there is an increased risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Not an epileptogenic anesthetic:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancuronium Pancuronium does not cause convulsions.

Highyeild:

Agents which can cause convulsions are: Methohexitone (that is why the agent of choice for ECT). Enflurane and Sevoflurane Metabolic product of atracurium, laudanosine. Local anesthetic toxicity. Preservative used in ketamine.

questions.text: The most common cause of anaphylactic reactions in the perioperative period:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibiotics As per a new (British) study it has been seen that the most common precipitating agents for anaphylaxis are antibiotics (53%) followed by neuromuscular blocking agents (33%), and then chlorhexidine (9%)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: As per the previous French study, the most common cause of anaphylaxis was muscle relaxants however a recent study has found muscle relaxants to be the second most common cause of anaphylaxis Option C: Latex allergy is the 4 th usual cause of anaphylaxis. Option D: All IV agents used in practice (particularly opioids) can cause anaphylaxis however anaphylaxis with IV agents is rare.

Extraedge:

Anaphylaxis has never been reported with inhalational agents.

questions.text: A 40-year female is being operated on for thyroidectomy. During surgery, she rapidly develops hyperthermia (temp. 108°F), tachycardia, and end-tidal CO2 > 90 mmHg. In premedication, she was given droperidol and atropine. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignant hyperthermia In malignant hyperthermia, the rise in fever is very rapid (1°C/5 minutes). The rise in ETCO2 to such high levels is seen in malignant hyperthermia.

Highyeild:

Causes of hyperthermia during anesthesia are: Thyrotoxicosis. Malignant hyperthermia. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Atropine. Injury to the hypothalamus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, C, and D : Hyperthermia can occur in all of the mentioned conditions however in the rest of the conditions ETCO2 will rise but not too high, and secondly fever will develop slowly.

questions.text: All of the following cause malignant hyperthermia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide has not been found to trigger malignant hyperthermia.

Highyeild:

Causative agents of malignant hyperthermia: Suxamethonium Halothane. Isoflurane. Enflurane. Desflurane. Sevoflurane

Extraedge:

Succinylcholine is the most commonly implicated drug to cause malignant hyperthermia Among the volatile agents, halothane is the most commonly implicated drug to trigger malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Which of the following agent can delay the onset of malignant hyperthermia (MH)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Option A: Depolarizing muscle relaxants (Suxamethonium) can precipitate MH while non-depolarizing muscle relaxants have the opposite effect. They may delay or even prevent malignant hyperthermia. Option B: Hypothermia can delay the onset of MH. Therefore, mild hypothermia should be instituted in patients susceptible of malignant hyperthermia. Option C: All IV induction agents are safe for patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia but Propofol is unique because it can delay the onset or even prevent malignant hyperthermia. Therefore, propofol is not only the induction agent of choice in Malignant Hyperthermia susceptible patients but is used as a continuous infusion to delay or prevent malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Not a feature of malignant hyperthermia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradycardia Due to sympathetic stimulation, there occurs tachycardia in malignant hyperthermia

Highyeild:

Clinical features of malignant hyperthermia are- Hyperthermia (temperature may rise to > 109°F) Increased end-tidal CO2 (CO2 may even rise to 90- 100 mmHg) - usually the earliest sign to appear Hyperkalemia Metabolic acidosis Tachycardia, hypertension, cardiac arrhythmia (hyperkalemia-induced ventricular fibrillation is the most common cause of death in these patients) Muscle rigidity, increased myoglobin, and increased creatinine kinase Renal failure, DIC Pulmonary or cerebral edema Death

Extraedge:

Malignant hyperthermia is an abnormality of the calcium release channel, ryanodine receptor, leading to the accumulation of calcium and sustained contraction. During this sustained contraction there is the hydrolysis of high-energy phosphates producing heat.

questions.text: A 62-year female is undergoing a hysterectomy under GA with O2+ N2O+ Sevoflurane. The patient developed hyperthermia of 1080C. The ETCO2 rose from 40 cmH2O to 78 cmH2O. The management of this patient includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above

Highyeild:

Specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia is Dantrolene sodium Non-specific management includes: Hyperventilation to wash out excess C02 Control of temperature, Treatment of acidosis Correction of hyperkalemia Maintain urine output to wash out myoglobin which may cause renal failure in the post-operative period

Extraedge:

Hyperkalemia should be managed as a top priority because hyperkalemia-induced ventricular fibrillation is the most common cause of death in malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of Malignant hyperthermia

options.label: A
options.text: Halothane and caffeine muscle contracture test

questions.correct_answer: A. Halothane and caffeine muscle contracture test
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Halothane and caffeine muscle contracture test Halothane and caffeine muscle contracture tests are considered as gold standard tests to rule out malignant hyperthermia. In this test, muscle biopsy taken from the quadriceps is subjected to caffeine and halothane to see the pathological changes of malignant hyperthermia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Creatinine kinase is done as the first basic test in susceptible patients to rule out malignant hyperthermia. If the levels are found to be elevated patient is labeled as susceptible, however, a negative test does not rule out susceptibility and the patient has to a undergo halothane caffeine contracture test to rule out malignant hyperthermia Option A: Tensilon test and Wokdart test are not done in anesthesia

questions.text: Most common nerve injured during anesthesia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulnar In the closed claims database study of the last 50 years, ulnar neuropathy is the most common lesion representing 28% of all peripheral nerve injury claims followed by the brachial plexus (20%), lumbosacral nerve root (16%), and spinal cord (13%).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Lateral popliteal is hardly involved during anesthesia Option C - femoral may be involved if there is excessive angulation at the thigh but its also rare Option D- Previous study showed the brachial plexus to be most commonly involved however recent evidence has shown the ulnar to be the most commonly involved nerve during general anesthesia

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient was undergoing posterior fossa craniotomy under GA. All of the following statements are true about air embolism except:

options.label: A
options.text: Air embolism occurs most frequently in a sitting position

options.label: B
options.text: The most sensitive test to detect air embolism is transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)

options.label: C
options.text: Left Lateral position should be instituted immediately once the diagnosis of air embolism is made

options.label: D
options.text: 100 ml of air is considered significant to cause an air embolism

questions.correct_answer: C. Left Lateral position should be instituted immediately once the diagnosis of air embolism is made
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left Lateral position should be instituted immediately once the diagnosis of air embolism is made The left lateral position is only recommended if there is a suspected Right to left shunt to prevent paradoxical embolism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- In a sitting position, cerebral veins are above the level of the heart, therefore have negative pressure. Opening of such a vein may lead to the sucking of air due to negative pressure. Posterior fossa craniotomies are performed in a sitting position, therefore, carries a high risk of venous air embolism Option B- Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive to diagnose an air embolism. The volume of air as low as 0.2 ml can be detected by TEE. Option D- Although any amount of air can cause significant air embolism however volume of more than 100 ml is considered significant

Extraedge:

Air reaching on the left side of circulation (mostly through ASD) is called a paradoxical embolism which is a dangerous complication; there may be coronary embolism leading to irreversible cardiac arrest, there may occur cerebral embolism leading to massive infarcts, there may occur renal embolism leading to renal failure. TEE is most sensitive to diagnose air embolism however it is not The most specific test is the sudden increase in end-tidal nitrogen.

questions.text: The most common ocular complication of general anesthesia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corneal abrasion Corneal abrasion is the most common however fortunately this is transient. This occurs because the patients blinking reflex is lost during GA. Therefore, lubricating and covering the eyes is one of the most important precautions to be taken during GA.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B- Ischemic optic neuropathy is one of the most dreadful complications leading to permanent blindness however is very rare. Most often, this complication occurs in surgeries done in a prone position if the eye is not properly protected and the patient develops hypotension. Options: C and D- Retinal detachment and Vitreal hemorrhages can also occur due to pressure on the eye however again are very rare.

questions.text: A 33-year-old with poorly controlled hyperthyroidism is undergoing an emergency cesarean section due to severe fetal distress. Her vitals are as follows: PR- 102/mt, BP-150/94mmHg. As there was no time to give, the spinal patient was given GA. After induction Pulsed rate increased to 150/mt. Which of the following beta blocker will be most preferred to control her heart rate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esmolol Esmolol has a rapid onset and short duration of action (half-life- 8-10 minutes) because it is metabolized by RBC esterase. Therefore, it is most commonly used to control perioperative tachycardia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Propranolol has slow onset therefore not preferred for acute emergencies. Option C- If Esmolol is not available then Metoprolol can be used as an alternative to esmolol Option D- Atenolol is also not used for emergencies

questions.text: The most common rhythm disturbance peri-operative period is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tachycardia In fact, all arrhythmias has been reported in the perioperative period however the most common cardiac arrhythmia in perioperative period is tachycardia and the usual causes of tachycardia are pain, agitation, hypovolemia, fever, hypoxemia, and hypercarbia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- The reasons for bradycardia may be Suxamethonium or inhalational agents like halothane Option B- Ventricular fibrillation is rare however can occur in vulnerable patients like MI or previously existing ventricular arrhythmias. Option D- excessive vagal stimulation particularly due to peritoneal stretching can convert a second-degree block to a complete heart block

questions.text: Postoperative restlessness is seen in all, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narcotic analgesia Narcotics and benzodiazepines will calm the patient.

Highyeild:

The usual causes of postoperative restlessness are: Pain. Full bladder. Hypoxia. Hypercarbia. Nausea and vomiting. Hypotension. Myocardial ischemia.

questions.text: The most common cause of postoperative renal failure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased renal perfusion Prerenal azotemia (Decreased renal perfusion) accounts for 90% of perioperative renal failure

Highyeild:

The causes of renal hypoperfusion Hypotension which in turn can be because of Hypovolemia All anesthetic agents are vasodilators so can cause hypotension Spinal and epidural also cause hypotension. Blood loss during surgery can decrease renal perfusion if hypotension is significant. Increased renal vascular resistance which is because of stress hormones released during surgery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Anesthetic agents can directly cause nephrotoxicity by producing fluoride. Option C : Antibiotic toxicity particularly aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity Option D : Direct injury during surgery can also cause renal failure

Extraedge:

In the past, maximum nephrotoxicity was reported with Methoxyflurane. Among the current-day agent, maximum fluoride is produced by Sevoflurane. On the other hand, minimum fluoride is produced by desflurane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient underwent laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy under GA. The most common postoperative complication expected in the recovery room
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nausea and vomiting As per the latest closed claim studies, Postoperative nausea and vomiting is the most common postoperative complication of general anesthesia, seen in >30% of the patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Previous closed-claim studies have described the pain as the most common post-op complication however recent studies have found pain to be the 2 nd most common post-op complication. Option C and D- Aspiration and atrial fibrillation can be seen but are rare.

questions.text: There are many causes of fire in the operation theatre. Static current is one of the important causes of fire. What should be done to prevent static electricity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Use cotton dresses The flow of gasses and movement of equipment in the operation theatre causes a static current which in case of electrical short circuits can cause fire and explosions. Nylon, synthetic, or woolen clothes increases the chances of catching the fire therefore only cotton clothes are permitted.

Highyeild:

Other measures recommended to prevent static current: The material coming in contact with the patient (like face masks) or surface (like wheels of an anesthesia machine) must contain an antistatic material like carbon. Floors should be conductive to dissipate the current As normal rubber creates static electricity therefore special rubber with antistatic properties should only be used. Static current is more generated in a dry atmosphere therefore humidity should be maintained at >60%

questions.text: Hypothermia is a common complication seen in GA due to multiple reasons. Which of the following is not the perioperative implication of hypothermia
questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased chances of myocardial ischemia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased chances of myocardial ischemia Hypothermia by causing shivering (which can increase oxygen requirement) can increase the chances of myocardial ischemia up to 3-fold in vulnerable patients.

Highyeild:

Hypothermia is common in the intraoperative period. There are multiple reasons which cause hypothermia like: All inhalational agents are vasodilators leading to heat loss from the body. Similarly, regional anesthesia like spinal/epidural also causes vasodilatation. Cold solutions like Betadine leads to further loss of heat Patient is exposed Operation theatre may be too cool (Ideal OT temp. 21 0 C adults & 24 0 C children) Intravenous fluids may not be at body temperature.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Hypothermia decreases the metabolism of anesthetic agents therefore can delay recovery Option C- A most common consequence of hypothermia is delayed wound healing because hypothermia inhibits the immune system. Option D- Hypothermia by inhibiting platelets and clotting cascade increases the requirement for blood transfusion.

questions.text: A 60-year female underwent a hysterectomy under GA. The recovery was smooth and the patient was shifted to the recovery room. After keeping in the recovery room for half an hour the nurse wants to shift her to the ward. Which of the following scales will she use to check the fitness for shifting to the ward?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alderate score Alderate score and post anesthesia discharge score are the 2 scoring systems used to assess the fitness of a patient for shifting to the ward.

Highyeild:

Alderate scoring system involves: Color of the patient (pink-2, pale-1, cyanotic 0). Respiration (normal-2, shallow-1, apnea-0). Circulation (BP within 20% of normal-2, within 50%-1, < 50%-0). Consciousness (awake-2, arousable-1, no response-0). Activity (moves 4 limbs-2, moves 2 limbs-1, no movement-0).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, and B- Visual analogue scale and McGill score are used for pain assessment Option D- Ramsay score is used to check sedation in ICU

questions.text: A patient who was given general anesthesia claimed that he was aware of intraoperative events and was able to hear the voices during surgery. The maximum possibility of drug combination used was:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

O2 + N2O + morphine Amnesia is an essential component of balanced Inadequate amnesia is one of an important cause of medico legal litigation against anesthetist in the western world. The most common type of awareness is auditory. Awareness is most common if a combination of oxygen, nitrous oxide, and opioid is used.

Highyeild:

To decrease this awareness and recall of events (amnesia): Patients should be premedicated with benzodiazepines. Anaesthesia should be maintained with inhalational agents.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A and B- Inhalational agents have been used so, there are very less chance of awareness Option D- Since midazolam is used so again there are less chances of inadequate amnesia.

questions.text: Post-operative pulmonary complications are seen in all of the following BMI>30 Upper abdominal surgery Patient with 7 pack years of smoking Age > 70 Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct One of the very important parts of preoperative evaluation is to determine the major risk factors which predispose the patient to postoperative pulmonary complications. The following factors have been cited as the major risk factors: Serum albumin < 3.5 g/dl Surgical factors like site of surgery (thoracic and upper abdominal), nature (major), and duration (> 3 hours) Surgery under general anesthesia Heavy smoker Congestive heart failure Age > 60 years Severity of pulmonary disease (Dyspnea at minimal activity) ASA grade > 2 Obesity (BMI> 30) – Obese patients have compromised lung functions Dyspnea at minimal activity and site of surgery are the 2 most important predictors of postoperative complications.

questions.text: The following are used for the treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting following squint surgery in children except: Ketamine Ondansetron Propofol Dexamethasone Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct Ketamine does not have any antiemetic properties. Drugs usually used for the treatment of nausea and vomiting are: Ondansetron (5 HT3 antagonist)/Granisetron – Agents of choice Metoclopramide Hyoscine Phenothiazines Dexamethasone Propofol because of its antiemetic properties can be used however generally not used

questions.text: Seen in Trendelenburg position: increased intracranial tension decreased cardiac output Increased intraocular pressure Decreased functional residual capacity Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 3, and 4 are correct 1 and 3 - Intracranial and intraocular tension is increased due to decreased venous return from the head and neck. 2- Cardiac output is increased due to increased venous return from the lower part of the body. 4- Head low position pushes the diaphragm upwards causing basal atelectasis of the lungs decreasing the functional residual capacity

questions.text: Which of the following statement is/are true Hypotension is the most common complication in postoperative period Most common cause of hypoxia in the postoperative period is hypoventilation Halothane is the most commonly implicated drug for malignant hyperthermia Most common cause of death in malignant hyperthermia is hyperthermia Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None is correct Nausea vomiting is the most common post-op complication The most common cause of postoperative hypoxia is V/Q mismatch caused by atelectasis of a segment or lobe. Hypoventilation is the second most common cause of hypoxia Succinylcholine is the most commonly implicated drug to cause malignant hyperthermia followed by halothane. Hyperkalemia-induced ventricular fibrillation is the most common cause of death in malignant hyperthermia
